Michael Scharf wrote:

> Hi,
>
> in http://www.robotstxt.org/wc/guidelines.html
> one of the guidelines says:
>
> Use If-modified-since or HEAD where possible
>   If your application can use the HTTP If-modified-since
>   header, or the HEAD method for its purposes, that
>   gives less overhead than full GETs.
>
> It seems heritrix does neither. At leas I could not find any
> code in head that would indicate the spider uses one
> of those.

>
> This is a problem for me, because I want to do incremental
> updates of spider runs. To do such an update there is no
> need to fetch a page that has already been fetched.
>
> Nor does it use HTTP/1/1 ETag 
>   http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.19
>
> Am I missing something here??

No. You are not missing anything. We don't do HTTP 1.1 nor do we have 
processors that look at if-modified-since or Etags.

On HTTP 1.1, your not the first to ask about it. In the past people have 
usually been interested in the keep-alive feature of HTTP/1.1 (See the 
'[896805] Consider use of HTTP/1.1 & kept-alive sockets' 
http://sourceforge.net/tracker/?group_id=73833&atid=539102&func=detail&aid=896805).  


For us here at the Archive, we wouldn't consider use of HTTP/1.1 until 
after we'd done work experimenting to see differences in server 
responses and after ensuring that downstream, the downloaded content 
doesn't make our postprocessing tools choke. This would be a significant 
undertaking.  It hasn't been a priority to date.

But that said, we'd be very much interested in a patch that optionally 
enabled HTTP/1.1 in the crawler and would like to hear about people's 
experiences crawling with 1.1 (We've  received a contribution to this 
end In the past from friends-of-Heritrix who needed HTTP/1.1 so Heritrix 
could pass NTLM authentication challenges but it was in need of work. If 
wanted, I could post the patch to the list given the author's 
permission).  For your usage scenario, since you don't need keep-alive, 
you might be able to get away with a small change making the crawler 
volunteer itself as HTTP/1.1 passing a 'Connection: close' header in 
with each request.

On Etags and dates, checkout this interesting paper by our Danish 
comrades: http://netarchive.dk/website/publications/Etags-2004.pdf.  
Here is a quote from the paper: "Not all servers send out Etags or even 
datestamps. Of the pages downloaded, only 3,321,598 (59.9%) had Etags. 
Datestamps are much more common, with 5,539,430 pages (99.93%) having a 
datestamp. Both indicators are fairly reliable, missing less than 1% of 
changed pages, the Etag missing less than 0.1%. They are somewhat 
conservative, and predict changes in up to one-third of pages that have 
not changed..."

Yours,
St.Ack
P.S. Apologize for not responding earlier to your note to the list of 
08/08/05, "[archive-crawler] Why is FetchHTTP using HTTP/1.0 and not 
HTTP/1.1?"
P.P.S I don't know of another crawler that does HTTP/1.1 but perhaps 
other on the lists know of such a beastie.
P.P.P.S The guidelines you cite, interestingly, are from 1993.
